millsfield:images_texts:
Welcome aboard the China Clipper II. Fifty years ago today, the China
Clipper, a Pan Am Martin M-130 flying boat, taxied out into the harbor of
San Francisco Bay and took off trailing a large wake of sea spray. Bands
played and flags waved. Cheering crowds lined the shores. A flotilla of
pleasure boats dotted the harbor and small planes flew overhead to
witness the historic event - the inauguration of the first commercial
Caper looming nestorace rine mom , Present Frankin
D. Roosevelt sent a special message "conveying heartfelt congratulations
of an airminded sailor."
Today, we commemorate this historic flight by retracing the route of the
China Clipper aboard a Boeing 747 Jet Clipper. The flight of the China
Clipper Il not only celebrates past achievements, but serves as a reminder
leave ances mine menand men i pronered and un air
routes across the Pacific. We are honored that you are joining Pan Am on
this nostalgic flight into history in salute to the China Clipper.
Shind Cal
• coward Ace
Chairman
PACIFIC OCEAN
n November 22, 1935 at 3:46 pm (local time), the China
Clipper took off from the Pan American operating base at
Alameda, California enroute to Manila. The route had
Am. The 8210-mie journey incide sos on by ar
Midway, Wake and Guam Islands, arriving in Manila exactly on schedule
on November 29. Total elapsed time was 6 days, 7 hours and 46 minutes.
Total flying time was 59 hours, 48 minutes.
Dior Captain Evin C. Muskin ormand. This ast massacic armall
flight carried 58 bags of mail with 110,865 letters bound for Honolulu,
Guam and Manila. Today, the China Clipper Il is carrying approximately
180,000 letters.

JUAM
nroute to Guam, Captain Musick radioed from the flight deck,
"Everything was functioning perfectly and the China Clipper
radio compass stations that kept their invisible fingers on us.
The China Clipper crossed the International Date Line and arrived in
Guam 45 minutes ahead of schedule. After a day of rest and Thanksgiving
dinner at the Governor's Palace, the crew of the China Clipper was ready
to embark on the final leg of their journey.
WAKE - GUAM

MANILA
he 1,600-mile leg from
Guam to Manila was the
only stretch that had never
before been flown on survey
missions ov ran Am in his
dispatch from Manila, Captain Musick
said: "As the rugged hills of the Philip-
pines appeared over the port bow
wady, the crew ore onina Clipper
came to a realization of the significance
of this achievement for American
aviation — a history-making 8,000-mile
flight in a four-motored transport plane
bearing the first transpacific mail from
Alameda, California to Manila."
Arriving in Manila right on schedule
at 3:32 pm local time on November
29, the China Clipper was greeted by
exuberant crowds. Asked by curious
reporters to describe their journey
Captain Musick simply stated: "The
flight was without incident."

properties.sfomuseum:description: Menu issued by Pan American World Airways, San Francisco - Manila route, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the first China Clipper flight on November 22, 1935; gray cover with color reproduction of illustration of Martin M-130 flying past the Golden Gate Bridge; menu items included for several meals; no menu number; undated (presumably November 22, 1985).
properties.wof:name: menu: Pan American World Airways, 50th anniversary of first flight of China Clipper
